MEDICAL NOTICE.

II is not when the warriors frown


Hath made the proudest armies bow;
II is not when the victor's crown


Is placed upon the warriors brow
II is not when nation pays


Such envied honors to his name.
Nor when surrounded by their blaze,


That dearest is the warriors fame.
Par dearer when the pitying tear


Is softly trembling in his eye,
Which rather mourns the carnage near,
Than gladdens at the victory.
And dearer still when in that hour


The warrior breathes the iowly prayer.
Nor boasts the aid of human power,


But owns "the hand Of Heaven" was there.
Printed and PublsheA Tuesday Friday, by
THE WARRIOR.

THE FUNERAL.


Written by little Girl of Lexington Ken, thirteen
years old after returning from the funeral Of schoolmae
Extracted from the Kentucky Reporter.


1t was picrcingly cold Sunday evening.-Th.
sun had hid itself behind the clouds, and Nature
scemed to have acted in unison with the feelings OF
my heart We prepared 10 attend the funeral OF
one of our former schoolmates who had been called
hence by death, while in the bloom Of youth and
beauty. On our way to the mournful scene, the
light lest, and reckless. careless laugh ct nv com
panions were heard, and we seemed to be amusing
ourselves by taking walk, rather than going 10
witness the awful ravages Of death in the face and
form OF our late companion. We saw the black
receptacle OF the coffin. ss il slowly approached the
door We reached the house. All was dark, lone.
and dreary a child showed US the way. We en-.
tered the crowded ahtcbamber. There saw
weeping cyet and breaking hearts. l pushed for
ward into the room, where lay the remains OF her
who was once eminently beautiful. amable and
conn plished. The room was darkened, but still
| few rays of light penetrated into this dreary abode
Of sorrow and death. | approached the coffin. She
appeared entirely altered. The rose that once
bloomed on her soft and delicate cheek, was now
sue cceeded by lily wheness; those eyes. that once
besmed with animation, with love, with in,ellieen
were now closed in death; their animated expires
| SION was ueO iOEefcE uC tdTi curry TiHSCtS that
once were spread, in Wild confusion, on her whre
neck, were now clipped and the lew that remained
were almost entirely concealed from our view, by
the cap of Grape. ray OF light suddenly illumina
ted the room. 1t fell on her countcnAnce and rem
dered her, to all appearance, alive. Her lips ap
peared 10 move. watched intensely lhe folds
Of her white shroud, which covered her breast, ap
peared to be gently ageated by her breath. fan
| cied she was alive IL was bu! fancy, and vain
one. thought of the hours which had spent with
| her but short year ago. She was then blooming.
gay, and happy had spent many hours with her
but few months since, In the festive ball room
but where was she now In her coffin q lifrless
heap OF clay Oh! wha, 4 warning again gazsd
on her, and wept She was clothed in white, in
the habiliments OF the grave and l---slill among
the living AT her feet was young and weeping
relation. gszed on her deceased, her loved
Sussnnah and she seemed as il she were willing
10 ioD the spirit OF her cousin. She gazed wistuIy
al the corpse. ~ il she would fain have share oi
that narrow coffin. One of Susan's brothers ap-
! preached he gazed on her pale lace; tear tell
on her marble features; he gazed again; he stoop
ed and pressed her lips, and starting up, darted has
tly from the room. The weeping cousin started
forward and Dressed burning, thrilling kiss. upon
the marble, icy purple lips of her beloved Susan
wcpt airesh 10 see the love which the brother
manifested towards his lost lsmented sister, and the
fondness with which the young creature wept III,
death OF her Susan. The man approached TO close
the coffin, and to shut her forever from the sight o
hsr weeping friends. turned away and wept il
sgory D; SOUL Every sound that vas made in nail
ing on the top oi the coffin went to my heart. wen
into porch to weep unrestranedly. saw younS
child standing IN corner weeping violently. Sh
ives asked what csused her to weep! Oh said she
they are going to bury sister, and then who will b
so good, so kind to me left her. It was too much
Oh how good being, TO be thus beloved by dc
crepid age and prattng youth. proceeded. III
coffin was lifted into the bier. We proceeded to tt
place Of interment and the coffin was carried to tn
grave. Ii was lowered. A brother to the dscease
s,ood nigh, and he shed no, tear Oh unf-eline
cruel man how can you refrain from mourning tn


loss Of such sister, when even the stranger weeps
But OH no. no it was rot There is an agon
o the heart deep for ulterance there is gris
which tears are no. permitted 10 express! The


proceeded to throw the earth over the coffin, an
every spadeful went to my heart. lett the groun


deeply convinced OF the uncertainty Of human life


Farewell to thee. sweet Susanosh! Oh may tn


stranger tread lightly thy tomb. young and lcyel


Girl and may thy soul find its way to the courts


heaven, and there abide Let the man OF feelin


drop q tear of sympathy. as he passes thy lowl


tomb let him weep at thy early death, for thou 10


vast a child OF fee'iog. and pitied the woes OF tn


unfortunate. We shall miss thy form and thy silve


voice in our plays, and thy light lsiry step IN tn


festive dance but the poor will miss thee more tc


thou vert the hope OF their desolate state. Oh


thou wilt surely be happy for thy voice and thy ste


were those of an angel scattering happiness!

I'M the United States Re1ieIp and Literary Gnxeffe
WEEP NOT FOR THE YOUTHFUL DEAD.
Weep not for the youthful dead,
Resting IN their peaceful bed
They are happier than we,
Howsoever blest we be.
They have lef, doubtful scene,
While their hearts were young and green,
Ere the s,ain Of guilt was deep;-
Wherefore. wherefore do ye weep!
1Hey have never known the stings
Which discovered friendship bringsS
Envy, Haired, Passion, Pride,
All lie buried at their side.
Far across the shipwreck foam,
They have found peaceful home,
Where the blessed spirits keep -
Wherefore. wherefore should ye weep
II is, We say, a heavy pain,
Prcyng on the heart in vain,
Thus 10 see It green bud froze,
When just opening TO rose.
YET shall Consolation come,
STOPPING from her starry homev
Bringing dew upon her wings.
From the deep, eternal springs
He had just begun to climb
Up the weary mount of Time;
Weep no, his untmey end.
If he sunk, i was to ascend.


She was young, and soft, and fair.
So her si,ter Sc raphs are


Wheref re, then, should Sorrow bow =!
She is with the seraphs now.
Happy they who die in youth,
Ere the fountain springs Of truth
Have been sullied by the rains,


Leaving dark and deadly stains.
Their renown is with the brave,


All their faults are in the grave,


And the flow ers, that round them bloom,
Chase the darkness.-hide the gloom.

From the United States Re7ev and Literary Gazette

MESSAGE FROM THE PRESIDENT U. STATES.


WAsHINoToS February 3, 1897.
To tie House Of Representatives. eftie Z. States:


In compliance with resolution of the House Of Repre-
senatives Of the Oh ut relating the appointments Of
Charges des Aares, and to the commissions and salaries
OF the Ministers Secretary TO the Mission to Panama,
transmit herewith report from the Secretary of State,


JOHN QUINCY ADAMS.


The Secretary of Slate whom has been referred the
resolution of the House Of Representatives of the 9th
ant, requesting tile President communicate tho
House "whether any, and if any, what number of Char
ges des Asres have been appointed the 4h day OF
March, l789 without the advice and consent of the Senate
and whether, any case, such appointment has been
made after notice had been given Of the intention Of
Minister abroad reurn and after his had been
appointed; if so BY what authority and what length OF
time did said temporary appointment continue, what the
general duties be discharged and wha, tile compenss-
ton paid. And that the Presden, also inform the House,
from what period the persons appointed Ministers aud
Secretary of Legation to Panama received their commits
sons and from what period they Rave been paid their
salarics;" has the honor to report


The resolution requires, first, information as to the MUM
Der of the appointments of Charges des Afares which
have been msde any, without the advice and consent of
the Senate the 4th day of March, 1889 Secondly
Whether in any such instances, the appointments were
made after notice had been given of the intention of
Minister abroad return aud after hs had beer
Iapponted. Thirdly, if so, by what authority, and for
what length Of time did such temporary appointments con-
ltinue. Fourhy, What the duties to he discharged
by Charge des Affares appointed Fifiy, What COM
pensaton did they receive and sxty from what period
the persons appointed Ministers Secretary If Legation
to Panama received their commissions, and from what
period they have been paid their salaries.


l. On the first point, the following stated from
the records of the Department Of State, in Of hic
except that of Mr Short the persons appointed
nominated to the Senate.


William Short nominated to the Senate on the i6,
Of June, 1889, Charge des Aaires at the Cout of
France daring the absence OF the Minister Penpo' enary
at that Cour (Thomss Jefferson, and commissioned
such the 9Th April, $780, during he pleasure OF the

State, and thereby vacated his office Mnster Penpo-
entiary to the Court of France w. Short without
further nomination to the Senate, was Commissioned as
above, there being Minister Plcnipntentlary at the

Jonathan Russell left in the charge Of our affairs al

THE WARRIOR.
full articles.article:
II is not when the warriors frown


Hath made the proudest armies bow;
II is not when the victor's crown


Is placed upon the warriors brow
II is not when nation pays


Such envied honors to his name.
Nor when surrounded by their blaze,


That dearest is the warriors fame.
Par dearer when the pitying tear


Is softly trembling in his eye,
Which rather mourns the carnage near,
Than gladdens at the victory.
And dearer still when in that hour


The warrior breathes the iowly prayer.
Nor boasts the aid of human power,


But owns "the hand Of Heaven" was there.

full articles.headline: THE FUNERAL.
full articles.article:
THE FUNERAL.


Written by little Girl of Lexington Ken, thirteen
years old after returning from the funeral Of schoolmae
Extracted from the Kentucky Reporter.


1t was picrcingly cold Sunday evening.-Th.
sun had hid itself behind the clouds, and Nature
scemed to have acted in unison with the feelings OF
my heart We prepared 10 attend the funeral OF
one of our former schoolmates who had been called
hence by death, while in the bloom Of youth and
beauty. On our way to the mournful scene, the
light lest, and reckless. careless laugh ct nv com
panions were heard, and we seemed to be amusing
ourselves by taking walk, rather than going 10
witness the awful ravages Of death in the face and
form OF our late companion. We saw the black
receptacle OF the coffin. ss il slowly approached the
door We reached the house. All was dark, lone.
and dreary a child showed US the way. We en-.
tered the crowded ahtcbamber. There saw
weeping cyet and breaking hearts. l pushed for
ward into the room, where lay the remains OF her
who was once eminently beautiful. amable and
conn plished. The room was darkened, but still
| few rays of light penetrated into this dreary abode
Of sorrow and death. | approached the coffin. She
appeared entirely altered. The rose that once
bloomed on her soft and delicate cheek, was now
sue cceeded by lily wheness; those eyes. that once
besmed with animation, with love, with in,ellieen
were now closed in death; their animated expires
| SION was ueO iOEefcE uC tdTi curry TiHSCtS that
once were spread, in Wild confusion, on her whre
neck, were now clipped and the lew that remained
were almost entirely concealed from our view, by
the cap of Grape. ray OF light suddenly illumina
ted the room. 1t fell on her countcnAnce and rem
dered her, to all appearance, alive. Her lips ap
peared 10 move. watched intensely lhe folds
Of her white shroud, which covered her breast, ap
peared to be gently ageated by her breath. fan
| cied she was alive IL was bu! fancy, and vain
one. thought of the hours which had spent with
| her but short year ago. She was then blooming.
gay, and happy had spent many hours with her
but few months since, In the festive ball room
but where was she now In her coffin q lifrless
heap OF clay Oh! wha, 4 warning again gazsd
on her, and wept She was clothed in white, in
the habiliments OF the grave and l---slill among
the living AT her feet was young and weeping
relation. gszed on her deceased, her loved
Sussnnah and she seemed as il she were willing
10 ioD the spirit OF her cousin. She gazed wistuIy
al the corpse. ~ il she would fain have share oi
that narrow coffin. One of Susan's brothers ap-
! preached he gazed on her pale lace; tear tell
on her marble features; he gazed again; he stoop
ed and pressed her lips, and starting up, darted has
tly from the room. The weeping cousin started
forward and Dressed burning, thrilling kiss. upon
the marble, icy purple lips of her beloved Susan
wcpt airesh 10 see the love which the brother
manifested towards his lost lsmented sister, and the
fondness with which the young creature wept III,
death OF her Susan. The man approached TO close
the coffin, and to shut her forever from the sight o
hsr weeping friends. turned away and wept il
sgory D; SOUL Every sound that vas made in nail
ing on the top oi the coffin went to my heart. wen
into porch to weep unrestranedly. saw younS
child standing IN corner weeping violently. Sh
ives asked what csused her to weep! Oh said she
they are going to bury sister, and then who will b
so good, so kind to me left her. It was too much
Oh how good being, TO be thus beloved by dc
crepid age and prattng youth. proceeded. III
coffin was lifted into the bier. We proceeded to tt
place Of interment and the coffin was carried to tn
grave. Ii was lowered. A brother to the dscease
s,ood nigh, and he shed no, tear Oh unf-eline
cruel man how can you refrain from mourning tn


loss Of such sister, when even the stranger weeps
But OH no. no it was rot There is an agon
o the heart deep for ulterance there is gris
which tears are no. permitted 10 express! The


proceeded to throw the earth over the coffin, an
every spadeful went to my heart. lett the groun


deeply convinced OF the uncertainty Of human life


Farewell to thee. sweet Susanosh! Oh may tn


stranger tread lightly thy tomb. young and lcyel


Girl and may thy soul find its way to the courts


heaven, and there abide Let the man OF feelin


drop q tear of sympathy. as he passes thy lowl


tomb let him weep at thy early death, for thou 10


vast a child OF fee'iog. and pitied the woes OF tn


unfortunate. We shall miss thy form and thy silve


voice in our plays, and thy light lsiry step IN tn


festive dance but the poor will miss thee more tc


thou vert the hope OF their desolate state. Oh


thou wilt surely be happy for thy voice and thy ste


were those of an angel scattering happiness!


=

full articles.headline:
From the United States Re7ev and Literary Gazette


WEEP NOT FOR THE YOUTHFUL DEAD.
full articles.article:
I'M the United States Re1ieIp and Literary Gnxeffe
WEEP NOT FOR THE YOUTHFUL DEAD.
Weep not for the youthful dead,
Resting IN their peaceful bed
They are happier than we,
Howsoever blest we be.
They have lef, doubtful scene,
While their hearts were young and green,
Ere the s,ain Of guilt was deep;-
Wherefore. wherefore do ye weep!
1Hey have never known the stings
Which discovered friendship bringsS
Envy, Haired, Passion, Pride,
All lie buried at their side.
Far across the shipwreck foam,
They have found peaceful home,
Where the blessed spirits keep -
Wherefore. wherefore should ye weep
II is, We say, a heavy pain,
Prcyng on the heart in vain,
Thus 10 see It green bud froze,
When just opening TO rose.
YET shall Consolation come,
STOPPING from her starry homev
Bringing dew upon her wings.
From the deep, eternal springs
He had just begun to climb
Up the weary mount of Time;
Weep no, his untmey end.
If he sunk, i was to ascend.


She was young, and soft, and fair.
So her si,ter Sc raphs are


Wheref re, then, should Sorrow bow =!
She is with the seraphs now.
Happy they who die in youth,
Ere the fountain springs Of truth
Have been sullied by the rains,


Leaving dark and deadly stains.
Their renown is with the brave,


All their faults are in the grave,


And the flow ers, that round them bloom,
Chase the darkness.-hide the gloom.

MESSAGE FROM THE PRESIDENT U. STATES.
full articles.article:
compensation To Dtpt0nGtlc agents.


MESSAGE FROM THE PRESIDENT U. STATES.


WAsHINoToS February 3, 1897.
To tie House Of Representatives. eftie Z. States:


In compliance with resolution of the House Of Repre-
senatives Of the Oh ut relating the appointments Of
Charges des Aares, and to the commissions and salaries
OF the Ministers Secretary TO the Mission to Panama,
transmit herewith report from the Secretary of State,


JOHN QUINCY ADAMS.


The Secretary of Slate whom has been referred the
resolution of the House Of Representatives of the 9th
ant, requesting tile President communicate tho
House "whether any, and if any, what number of Char
ges des Asres have been appointed the 4h day OF
March, l789 without the advice and consent of the Senate
and whether, any case, such appointment has been
made after notice had been given Of the intention Of
Minister abroad reurn and after his had been
appointed; if so BY what authority and what length OF
time did said temporary appointment continue, what the
general duties be discharged and wha, tile compenss-
ton paid. And that the Presden, also inform the House,
from what period the persons appointed Ministers aud
Secretary of Legation to Panama received their commits
sons and from what period they Rave been paid their
salarics;" has the honor to report


The resolution requires, first, information as to the MUM
Der of the appointments of Charges des Afares which
have been msde any, without the advice and consent of
the Senate the 4th day of March, 1889 Secondly
Whether in any such instances, the appointments were
made after notice had been given of the intention of
Minister abroad return aud after hs had beer
Iapponted. Thirdly, if so, by what authority, and for
what length Of time did such temporary appointments con-
ltinue. Fourhy, What the duties to he discharged
by Charge des Affares appointed Fifiy, What COM
pensaton did they receive and sxty from what period
the persons appointed Ministers Secretary If Legation
to Panama received their commissions, and from what
period they have been paid their salaries.


l. On the first point, the following stated from
the records of the Department Of State, in Of hic
except that of Mr Short the persons appointed
nominated to the Senate.


William Short nominated to the Senate on the i6,
Of June, 1889, Charge des Aaires at the Cout of
France daring the absence OF the Minister Penpo' enary
at that Cour (Thomss Jefferson, and commissioned
such the 9Th April, $780, during he pleasure OF the
Presden, OF the United States Thomas Jefferson was,
on the 26th Of September 1889 appointed Secretary of
State, and thereby vacated his office Mnster Penpo-
entiary to the Court of France w. Short without
further nomination to the Senate, was Commissioned as
above, there being Minister Plcnipntentlary at the
Court of France until the appointment of Gouverneur
Norris 18th January, 1872 Mr.. Shor was presented as
Charge des Aares by MIR Jefferson, on his taking leave
the French Court, the authority OF letter from Mr.
Jay, ary Of Foreign Affairs Of the 18th june 1897
Which also permitted that Minister'S visit TO the
United States.


John purviance vas ef in the charge of our affairs
at London the 9Th of October. 1904, BY Mr. Monroe
during his absence in SPAIN


George W. Ervng was appointed Secretary Of L-ga-
ton Madrid, with the advice and of the Senate,
22d Novembe 1904; and appointed Professionally by the
President, without the cooperation of the Sena to act
Charges des Afses at Madrid, until the arrival Of Mr.
Bowdon, appointed Minister 22d of November 1904.


Jonathan Russell left in the charge Of our affairs al
Pa by General Armstrong, and commissioned such b.
tue President.


John S Smith was left Charge des Aares at London.
by MIR Pinckney, LIST May. l81t but no commission eve.
issued to him AS such.


Jonathan Russell was by the direction cf the res
dent from Paris to London. in October 1911, as Charge
dies Atfailes.


Levitt, Harris was left Charge des Aaires ST. Peters
burg, by Mr.. Adams, in April 1914 By direction Of the


John L. Lawrence. lef, Charge des Afares at Stock
holm, by NJ. RUSSELL 9th June, 1914


Henry jackson, left Charge des Aalres al Paris BY Mr.
Cra wford 26h April, 1915, while Mr. Gaatn, appointed
Minister to France, 2Sh February, 1915, was in London
assisting the negotiation OF the Convention OF that


Thomas l.. L. Brent Secretary OF Legation at Madiid
was left Charge des hfaires there by Mr.. Er.ing ir
August, 1915.


And again. by Mr. Forsyth esd November, 1890 dur
ing his return, on leave, to the United STATES.


Christopher Hughes, Secretary Of Legation & Stock
holm was designated by the President act Charge
des AHaires. The oh September. 1916, in the event
the retirement Of MIR. Russell, and he accordingly 81
left by Mr.. Russell in October 1918


Charles Plnckney, left Charge des Affaires al st. Pc
tersburg by Mr. Pnckney, il February, 1918 MIR Camp
bell was appointed Minister 10th April 1915


He was again left here charge Of our affairs, by Mr.
Campbell Sh July, 1890, by the ecton of the Presden,
Mr.. Middleton sppointed Minister 9th April. h iha
year.
John James Appleton was left Charge des Atfaires .
Madrid, by Mr.. Forsyth. Sd March, 1923 Mr.. Nelso
was appon'ed Minister 18th January, 1923


Daniel Sheldon, left Charge des Ahsires at Paris, b
Mr. Galatin, 10Th May, 1923, under the drec ion Of th
, President


Mr. Adams, in June, 1917 by order OF the President
lie again left in charge of affairs. by Nr Rsl


in May 1885, under the direction of ,he President. Nj
. King appointed Minister s'h May. 1925
John NJ. Forbes became Charge des .tiares al Buenc
i Ayres on the death of Mr.. dney, 10h June, 1894 II
was afterwards nominated the Senate in THAI charac,e
4 and confirmed 9Th of March, 1926
! John A. King lef, Charge des AHsIFes at London,


Rufus King 1st July, 1896 with the approba'ion Of tn
" President Mr. Gastn was appointed Minister, 10th Ma
1926 -
lie was again left in charge Of our affairs by Mr. Gaa

Beaufort r. Watts left Charge des Aares at Bogcta
